tit.e: Kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the court nobles called the kuge)
Kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the court nobles called the kuge)
Kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the court nobles called the kuge)

sen.j: 公家領（くげりょう）とは、公家（公卿・官人）の所領の総称。
sen.e: The term 'kuge-ryo' is the generic name for landed holdings belonging to 'kuge' (Japanese imperial court nobles) which includes 'kugyo' (high court nobles of third rank or above) and 'kanjin' (government officials), where the 'kugyo' consists of [1] 'ko' which includes the 'daijo daijin' (the Great Minister of State or Chancellor), the 'sa daijin' (Minister of the Left) and the 'u daijin' (Minister of the Right), and [2] 'kei' which includes 'dainagon' (Major Counselor), 'chunagon' (Middle Counselor) and 'sangi' (Consultants of senior fourth rank).
sen.cmt: 「公卿」 公(こう)と卿(けい)の総称。公は太政大臣・左大臣・右大臣、卿は大納言・中納言・参議および三位以上の朝官をいう。参議は（正）四位も含める。」（大辞泉） 公家の説明・理解には右記NYアルバニー大学サイトの訳語を参考にしました。http://www.albany.edu/eas/205/rank%20chart.htm 各役職の訳語は、アメリカ英語での翻訳ということですので、Harvard, Stanford大の研究書による訳語を優先しました。The Cambridge history of Japan (CHJ) も権威ある研究書ですが、基本的にイギリス英語ですので、参考にとどめています。
sen.e: The term 'kuge-ryo' is the generic name for landed holdings belonging to 'kuge' (Japanese imperial court nobles) which includes 'kugyo' (high court nobles of third rank or above) and 'kanjin' (government officials), where the 'kugyo' consists of [1] 'ko' which includes the 'daijo daijin' (the Great Minister of State or Chancellor), the 'sa daijin' (Minister of the Left) and the 'u daijin' (Minister of the Right), and [2] 'kei' which includes 'dainagon' (Major Counselor), 'chunagon' (Middle Counselor) and 'sangi' (Consultants of senior fourth rank).

The term 'kuge-ryo' is the generic name for landed holdings belonging to 'kuge' (Japanese imperial court nobles) which includes 'kugyo' (high court nobles of third rank or above) and 'kanjin' (government officials), where the 'kugyo' consists of [1] 'ko' which includes the 'daijo daijin' (the Great Minister of State or Chancellor), the 'sa daijin' (Minister of the Left) and the 'u daijin' (Minister of the Right), and [2] 'kei' which includes 'dainagon' (Major Counselor), 'chunagon' (Middle Counselor) and 'sangi' (Consultants of senior fourth rank).

sen.j: 広義においては皇室領を含む場合もある。
sen.e: In a wider context the term 'kuge-ryo' can include 'koshitu-ryo' which means imperial landholdings.
In a wider context the term 'kuge-ryo' can include the estate of the imperial household.
sen.cmt: 皇室領の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: In a wider context the term 'kuge-ryo' can include the estate of the imperial household.

sen.j: 古代律令制においては、公卿以下の官人を構成する貴族階層の生活は律令法で定められた封禄制度によって支えられてきた。
sen.e: According to the Ancient 'ritsuryo sei' (Japanese legal system), the nobility which consisted of 'kugyo' and lower-ranked 'kanjin' (government officials) enjoyed several sources of income based on the 'horoku seido' (stipend system) which was designated by the 'ritsuryo ho' (ritsuryo law).

According to the Ancient 'ritsuryo sei' (Japanese legal system), the living of the nobility which consisted of 'kugyo' and lower-ranked 'kanjin' (government officials) was secured by the income based on the 'horoku seido' (stipend system) which was designated by the 'ritsuryo ho' (ritsuryo law).
sen.cmt: the living を挿入し、enjoyed several souces of→was secured by the と修正しました。
sen.e: According to the Ancient 'ritsuryo sei' (Japanese legal system), the living of the nobility which consisted of 'kugyo' and lower-ranked 'kanjin' (government officials) was secured by the income based on the 'horoku seido' (stipend system) which was designated by the 'ritsuryo ho' (ritsuryo law).

sen.j: だが、その体制は早い時期に崩壊し、貴族たちは官司をも巻き込んで彼らによる独自の生活基盤形成を図ることになる。
sen.e: The stipend system according to the ritsuryo law, however, collapsed at an early stage, and the nobles attempted to develop their own infrastructures, involving 'guji' (chief priests of shinto shrines).

The stipend system according to the ritsuryo law, however, collapsed at an early stage, and the nobles attempted to develop their own infrastructures, involving 'guji' (chief priests of shinto shrines).

The stipend system according to the ritsuryo law, however, collapsed at an early stage, and the nobles attempted to develop their own infrastructures, involving 'guji' (chief priests of shinto shrines).

sen.j: 既に奈良時代の段階で有力貴族たちは山野薮沢を占有し、墾田永年私財法を利用して墾田を私有化して自己の所領を形成する。
sen.e: Already in the Nara period, dominating nobles occupied the countryside and established their own territories by privatizing reclaimed lands in accordance with an Act for the Privatization of Reclaimed Lands in Perpetuity.

Already in the Nara period, dominating nobles occupied the countryside and established their own territories by privatizing reclaimed lands in accordance with the Act for the Privatization of Reclaimed Lands in Perpetuity.

Already in the Nara period, dominating nobles occupied the countryside and established their own territories by privatizing reclaimed lands in accordance with the Act for the Privatization of Reclaimed Lands in Perpetuity.

sen.j: 9世紀末期には貴族による荘家が設置されて周囲の土地や舎宅を自己のものとして押領し、続いて官司も官人の俸禄や経費調達のために官田や諸司田を設置するようになる。
sen.e: At the end of the ninth century, manor houses are built by nobles so as to unlawfully seize and privatize the surrounding lands and 'shataku' (residence), which was followed by guji (shrine priests) who began to set up 'kanden' (imperial estates) and 'shoshiden' (tax-exempt lands that were provided to cover the labor cost of shoshi officials) in order to prepare 'horoku' (retainer's salary) to be paid to kanjin (government officials) and the other necessary expenses.

At the end of the ninth century, manor houses are built by nobles so as to unlawfully seize and privatize the surrounding lands and 'shataku' (residence), which was followed by guji (shrine priests) who began to set up 'kanden' (imperial estates) and 'shoshiden' (tax-exempt lands that were provided to cover the labor cost of shoshi officials) in order to prepare 'horoku' (retainer's salary) to be paid to kanjin (government officials) and the other necessary expenses.

At the end of the ninth century, manor houses are built by nobles so as to unlawfully seize and privatize the surrounding lands and 'shataku' (residence), which was followed by guji (shrine priests) who began to set up 'kanden' (imperial estates) and 'shoshiden' (tax-exempt lands that were provided to cover the labor cost of shoshi officials) in order to prepare 'horoku' (retainer's salary) to be paid to kanjin (government officials) and the other necessary expenses.

sen.j: 10世紀になると国司による徴税請負体制が確立し、皇室や上流貴族、官司はこうした国司からの進納に依存するところが大きくなる。
sen.e: It was in the tenth century when the system to undertake an actual tax collection by kokushi (provincial governors) was established, and accordingly, imperial households, high court nobles and guji financially depended upon 'shinno' (gifts) from the kokushi.

It was in the 10th century when the system to undertake an actual tax collection by kokushi (provincial governors) was established, and accordingly, imperial households, high court nobles and guji financially depended upon 'shinno' (gifts) from the kokushi.

It was in the 10th century when the system to undertake an actual tax collection by kokushi (provincial governors) was established, and accordingly, imperial households, high court nobles and guji financially depended upon 'shinno' (gifts) from the kokushi.

sen.j: 一方、中下流の貴族は国司として地方に下り土着する者が出る一方で受領となって財を築きあるいは荘園を築き、皇室や摂関家などと関係を結ぶ者があった。
sen.e: On the contrary, some middle- or low-class nobles, who had been appointed kokushi to rule a local province, decided to settle in the same area, whereas the others became 'zuryo' (custodial governors) and made fortunes or expanded shoen holdings, thus establishing relationships with the imperial family and 'sekkan-ke' (the families which had produced the regents and the chief advisors to the emperor).

On the other hand, some middle and lower class nobles, who had been appointed kokushi to rule a local province, decided to settle in the same area, whereas the others became 'zuryo' (custodial governors) and made fortunes or expanded shoen holdings, thus establishing relationships with the Imperial family and 'sekkan-ke' (the families which had produced the regents and the chief advisors to the emperor).
sen.cmt: contrary→other hand, middle- or low-class→middle and lower class,imperial→Imperial と修正しました。
sen.e: On the other hand, some middle and lower class nobles, who had been appointed kokushi to rule a local province, decided to settle in the same area, whereas the others became 'zuryo' (custodial governors) and made fortunes or expanded shoen holdings, thus establishing relationships with the Imperial family and 'sekkan-ke' (the families which had produced the regents and the chief advisors to the emperor).

sen.j: 受領や在庁官人は自らが築いた荘園をこうした有力者に積極的に寄進して自らは荘官としての地位を確実なものとした。
sen.e: Those zuryo and zaichokanjin (local officials) consolidated their positions as shokan (an officer governing shoen manors) by voluntarily donating shoen manors which they had created to influential magnates.

Those zuryo and zaichokanjin (local officials) consolidated their positions as shokan (an officer governing shoen manor) by voluntarily donating shoen manors which they had created to influential magnates.

Those zuryo and zaichokanjin (local officials) consolidated their positions as shokan (an officer governing shoen manor) by voluntarily donating shoen manors which they had created to influential magnates.

sen.j: 更に皇室や摂関家と人身的従属関係にある人々が給免田を与えられて供御人などとなり、彼らによって荘園が形成される場合もあった。
sen.e: Moreover, people who were personally subordinate to the imperial and the sekkan-ke families were granted kyumenden (tax free rice fields provided as salary), thereby becoming kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) and thus creating shoen manors.

Moreover, people who were personally subordinated to the imperial and the sekkan-ke families were granted kyumenden (tax free rice fields provided as salary), thereby becoming kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) and thus creating shoen manors.

Moreover, people who were personally subordinated to the imperial and the sekkan-ke families were granted kyumenden (tax free rice fields provided as salary), thereby becoming kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) and thus creating shoen manors.

sen.j: こうした中で国司側に残された田地も国衙領として実質上は国家（朝廷及び公家政権）の荘園となり、これを基礎とした院宮分国・知行国制度も確立された。
sen.e: In this way, rice fields which remained at the side of kokushi turned into de facto national estates (owned by the imperial court or the kuge [imperial] regime), and the 'ingu bunkoku sei' (provincial allotment system) and the 'chigyokoku seido' (possessory provinces system) were established on the basis of such national estates.

In this way, rice fields which remained to the kokushi turned into de facto national estates (owned by the imperial court or the kuge [imperial] regime), and the 'ingu bunkoku sei' (provincial allotment system) and the 'chigyokoku seido' (possessory provinces system) were established on the basis of such national estates.
sen.cmt: at the side of →to the と修正しました。
sen.e: In this way, rice fields which remained to the kokushi turned into de facto national estates (owned by the imperial court or the kuge [imperial] regime), and the 'ingu bunkoku sei' (provincial allotment system) and the 'chigyokoku seido' (possessory provinces system) were established on the basis of such national estates.

sen.j: 中世公家領には自己邸宅の宅地や御願寺・氏寺の敷地及び寺社領も含まれるが、収入を得るのは自家の荘園が主であった。
sen.e: Medieval kuge-ryo (landholdings of court nobles) included the land of their own residence, properties of goganji (a temple for an imperial family) and uji-dera temples (which had been built for praying clan's glory) and jisha-ryo (landholdings of temples and shrines), but the main source of income was their private shoen manors.

Medieval kuge-ryo (landholdings of court nobles) included the land of their own residence, properties of goganji (a temple for the Imperial Family) and uji-dera temples (which had been built for praying clan's glory) and jisha-ryo (landholdings of temples and shrines), but the main source of income was their private shoen manors.
sen.cmt: ”御願寺”を修正しました。（マイページとは異なりますが、the を挿入しました）
sen.e: Medieval kuge-ryo (landholdings of court nobles) included the land of their own residence, properties of goganji (a temple for the Imperial Family) and uji-dera temples (which had been built for praying clan's glory) and jisha-ryo (landholdings of temples and shrines), but the main source of income was their private shoen manors.

sen.j: 支配の形態は摂関家と清華家以下では大きく異なっている（皇室領の場合には、摂関家のそれに近い形態を取っていた）。
sen.e: It was very different between the sekkan-ke families and the seiga-ke families (the second highest family status for court nobles) as to how they administered an estate (for instance, administration of the imperial estate was close to that of the sekkan-ke family.)

It was very different between the sekkan-ke families and the seiga-ke families (the second highest family status for court nobles) as to how they administered an estate (for instance, administration of the imperial estate was close to that of the sekkan-ke family.)

It was very different between the sekkan-ke families and the seiga-ke families (the second highest family status for court nobles) as to how they administered an estate (for instance, administration of the imperial estate was close to that of the sekkan-ke family.)

sen.j: 五摂家の確立以後、摂関の官職・藤氏長者の地位・渡領（殿下渡領）がセットで五摂家の当主間を交替で移動した。
sen.e: After the establishment of Gosekke (five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of sessho [regent] and kanpaku [the chief advisor of the emperor]), a set of the government post of sessho or kanpaku, the position of To-shi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan) and watari-ryo (or denka no watari-ryo, which was the land the Fujiwara family hereditarily succeeded) were passed round among heads of the Gosekke families.

After the establishment of Gosekke (five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of sessho [regent] and kanpaku [the chief advisor of the emperor]), a set of the government post of sessho or kanpaku, the position of To-shi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan) and watari-ryo (or denka no watari-ryo, which was the land the Fujiwara family hereditary succeeded) were passed round among the heads of the Gosekke families.

After the establishment of Gosekke (five top Fujiwara families whose members were eligible for the positions of sessho [regent] and kanpaku [the chief advisor of the emperor]), a set of the government post of sessho or kanpaku, the position of To-shi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan) and watari-ryo (or denka no watari-ryo, which was the land the Fujiwara family hereditary succeeded) were passed round among the heads of the Gosekke families.

sen.j: 渡領とは別個に五摂家は家領と呼ばれる各家固有の所領を有していた。
sen.e: In addition to the watari-ryo, the Gosekke families possessed their own private estate which was called keryo (the original ancestral holding of a family).
In addition to the watari-ryo, the Gosekke families possessed their own private estates which were called keryo (the original ancestral holding of a family).
In addition to the watari-ryo, the Gosekke families possessed their own private estates which were called keryo (the original ancestral holding of a family).

sen.j: 家領は全て本家職を有しているか、 本所として荘務を掌握している所領のみで成立しており、皇室領も含めた他の荘園の下級所職を知行している例はなかった。
sen.e: All the keryo consisted solely of lands which had honke shiki (the right that the head family had) or controlling shomu (shoen administration) as honjo (the principal, which was a chief tenant and almost always a religious institution), and there was no example of controlling kakyu shoshiki (a low class officer governing a shoen estate) of the other shoen including the imperial estate.

All the keryo consisted solely of lands which had honke shiki (the right that the head family had) or controlling shomu (shoen administration) as honjo (the principal, which was a chief tenant and almost always a religious institution), and there was no example of controlling kakyu shoshiki (a low class officer governing a shoen estate) of the other shoen including the imperial estate.

All the keryo consisted solely of lands which had honke shiki (the right that the head family had) or controlling shomu (shoen administration) as honjo (the principal, which was a chief tenant and almost always a religious institution), and there was no example of controlling kakyu shoshiki (a low class officer governing a shoen estate) of the other shoen including the imperial estate.

sen.j: 清華家級の場合、皇室領（主に上皇や女院の所領）の領家職・預所職の知行が主で本家・本所となり得る家領は自己が開発に関わったものなどに限定されている。
sen.e: In the case of a family whose class was as high as seiga-ke family, ryoke shiki (proprietorships) and azukaridokoro shiki (the right that azukaridokoro or a custodian held) of the imperial estates (of the retired emperor or empress in particular) were mainly controlled, and keryo which could become honke or honjo (property of the head family or the principal institution) was limited to those which had directly been developed by the family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the case of a family whose class was as high as seiga-ke family, ryoke shiki (proprietorship) and azukaridokoro shiki (the right that azukaridokoro or a custodian held) of the imperial estates (of the retired emperor or empress in particular) were mainly controlled, and keryo which could become honke or honjo (property of the head family or the principal institution) was limited to those which had directly been developed by the family.

In the case of a family whose class was as high as seiga-ke family, ryoke shiki (proprietorship) and azukaridokoro shiki (the right that azukaridokoro or a custodian held) of the imperial estates (of the retired emperor or empress in particular) were mainly controlled, and keryo which could become honke or honjo (property of the head family or the principal institution) was limited to those which had directly been developed by the family.

sen.j: （これはそれ以下の公家も同様で、資力・政治力がない分一層厳しいものになる）
sen.e: (This applied to kuge whose class was below that of the seiga-ke families, but the control of estate affairs was even harder for them without funds and political power.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (This applied to some kuge whose class were lower that of the seiga-ke families, but the control of estate affairs was even harder for them without funds and political power.)
sen.cmt: some を挿入し、was→were,below→lower と修正しました。
sen.e: (This applied to some kuge whose class were lower that of the seiga-ke families, but the control of estate affairs was even harder for them without funds and political power.)

sen.j: それでも、彼らのうちには知行国を有して子孫に世襲させる例もあった（上野国の中院家、伊予国の西園寺家など）。
sen.e: Even so, some of the kuge possessed a chigyo koku (provincial fiefdom) and its succession was hereditary (e.g. the Nakanoin family of the Kamitsuke Province, the Saionji family of the Iyo Province, and the like.)

Even so, some of the kuge possessed chigyo koku (provincial fiefdom) and its succession was hereditary (e.g. the Nakanoin family of the Kozuke Province, the Saionji family of the Iyo Province, and the like).
sen.cmt: a を削除し、Kamitsuke→Kozuke Province,ピリオドの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: Even so, some of the kuge possessed chigyo koku (provincial fiefdom) and its succession was hereditary (e.g. the Nakanoin family of the Kozuke Province, the Saionji family of the Iyo Province, and the like).

sen.j: それ以下の公家の場合は、皇室や摂関家の家司・家礼として代々奉仕して、その俸禄の代わりに所領の下級所職が宛がわれる例が多い。
sen.e: In the case of the other kuge who did not possess a chigyo koku, they served as a keishi (household superintendent) or a kerei (lower class kuge who served the superior kuge) for generations, so that they were often granted shoshiki (the right of an officer governing a shoen estate) of a shoryo (fief) in lieu of horoku (stipend).

In the case of the other kuge who did not possess chigyo koku, they served as keishi (household superintendent) or kerei (lower class kuge who served the superior kuge) for generations, so that they were often granted the shoshiki (the right of an officer governing a shoen estate) of shoryo (fief) in the lieu of horoku (stipend).
sen.cmt: a を削除し、the を挿入しました。
sen.e: In the case of the other kuge who did not possess chigyo koku, they served as keishi (household superintendent) or kerei (lower class kuge who served the superior kuge) for generations, so that they were often granted the shoshiki (the right of an officer governing a shoen estate) of shoryo (fief) in the lieu of horoku (stipend).

sen.j: 中下級の公家の所領は大きく分けて「相伝」と「恩領」の2つに分れていた。
sen.e: The shoryo (fief) of the kuge of a middle- or low-class was largely classified into two kinds: 'soden (hereditary succession) and 'onryo' (rewarded land).
The shoryo (fief) of the kuge of a middle and lower class was largely classified into two kinds: 'soden' (hereditary succession) and 'onryo' (rewarded land).
sen.cmt: middle- or low-class→middle and lower class, クォーツを修正しました。
sen.e: The shoryo (fief) of the kuge of a middle and lower class was largely classified into two kinds: 'soden' (hereditary succession) and 'onryo' (rewarded land).

sen.j: 前者はその家に代々伝えられてきた所領・所職として子孫への継承が許された土地であり、後者は奉仕の代償として本家・本所から与えられた所領・所職でその付与・剥奪は本家・本所側にあった。
sen.e: The former, soden, was a piece of land for which hereditary succession as the shoryo (territory) and shoshiki (the right of a shoen governor) by the descendents of an owner family was allowed, whereas the latter, onryo, was the shoryo and shoshiki which had been granted by the honke (the head family) and the honjo (the principal institution and a chief tenant) as a reward in return for service, and the right to grant or deprive of the fief was held by the honke and honjo.

The former, soden, was a piece of land for which hereditary succession as the shoryo (territory) and shoshiki (the right of a shoen governor) by the descendents of an owner family was allowed, whereas the latter, onryo, was the shoryo and shoshiki which had been granted by the honke (the head family) and the honjo (the principal institution and a chief tenant) as the reward in return for service, and the right to grant or deprive of the fief was held by the honke and honjo.

The former, soden, was a piece of land for which hereditary succession as the shoryo (territory) and shoshiki (the right of a shoen governor) by the descendents of an owner family was allowed, whereas the latter, onryo, was the shoryo and shoshiki which had been granted by the honke (the head family) and the honjo (the principal institution and a chief tenant) as the reward in return for service, and the right to grant or deprive of the fief was held by the honke and honjo.

sen.j: もっとも、相伝であっても他者からの侵奪を避けるために有力権門である本家・本所による保障を受ける例や恩領であったものが長年の奉公の褒賞として相伝として本家・本所から認められる例もあった。
sen.e: Note that, there were such exceptions that, in order to avoid being plundered by usurpers, a soden was secured by the powerful honke and honjo, and that an onryo was approved as a soden by the honke and honjo, as a reward for longtime service.

Note that, there were such exceptions that, in order to avoid being plundered by others, a soden was secured by the powerful honke and honjo, and that an onryo was approved as a soden by the honke and honjo, as a reward for longtime service.

Note that, there were such exceptions that, in order to avoid being plundered by others, a soden was secured by the powerful honke and honjo, and that an onryo was approved as a soden by the honke and honjo, as a reward for longtime service.

sen.j: そのため、個々の公家領が相伝か恩領かを巡って本家（皇室・摂関家）と領家（中下級公家）の間で対立する場合もあった。
sen.e: Therefore, a conflict occasionally arose between the honke (the imperial and sekkan-ke families) and ryoke (the kuge of a middle- or low-class) as to whether an individual kuge-ryo territory was a soden or an onryo.

Therefore, a conflict occasionally arose between the honke (the imperial and sekkan-ke families) and the ryoke (the kuge of a middle and lower class) as to whether an individual kuge-ryo territory was a soden or an onryo.
sen.cmt: middle- or low-class→middle and lower class, the を挿入しました。
sen.e: Therefore, a conflict occasionally arose between the honke (the imperial and sekkan-ke families) and the ryoke (the kuge of a middle and lower class) as to whether an individual kuge-ryo territory was a soden or an onryo.

sen.j: また、家職の世襲によって当該官司が有する官司領を実質的に保有する場合（主殿寮の壬生官務家、内蔵寮の山科家など）もあった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, there was a case that a certain guji (a chief priest of a shrine) possessed guji-ryo territory de facto by hereditary succession of kashoku (profession and post which were inherited within a family, and particularly the privileges approved by the administrative authority in return for the retainership) (e.g. the Mibu Kanmu family of Shudenryo [which was also called Tonomoryo and was the Bureau of Grounds] and the Yamashina family of Kuraryo [Palace Storehouse Bureau]).

Meanwhile, there was a case that certain guji (a chief priest of a shrine) possessed guji-ryo territory by the hereditary succession of kashoku (profession and post which were inherited within a family, and particularly the privileges approved by the administrative authority in return for the retainership) (e.g. the Mibu Kanmu family of Shudenryo [which was also called Tonomoryo and was the Bureau of Grounds] and the Yamashina family of Kuraryo [Palace Storehouse Bureau]).
sen.cmt: a, de facto を削除しました。
sen.e: Meanwhile, there was a case that certain guji (a chief priest of a shrine) possessed guji-ryo territory by the hereditary succession of kashoku (profession and post which were inherited within a family, and particularly the privileges approved by the administrative authority in return for the retainership) (e.g. the Mibu Kanmu family of Shudenryo [which was also called Tonomoryo and was the Bureau of Grounds] and the Yamashina family of Kuraryo [Palace Storehouse Bureau]).

sen.j: 更に鎌倉時代以後の貨幣経済の発達に乗って官司の供御人の系譜を引く座や商工業者（官司の代わりに生産物を生産・調達して官司に納める義務を有するとされていた）に対する課役権を行使（京都における営業権の意味合いもある）や関所・率分所の設置による収入なども公私の経済の資を支えた。
sen.e: Furthermore, as monetary economy had developed in and after the Kamakura period, the kaeki-ken right (the right to levy duty, which was alternatively considered as the trade rights in Kyoto) was exercised against 'za' (trade guilds) which had been descended from kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) as well as merchants and traders (who had to provide guji on his behalf with the produce and products by means of production and acquisition), and an income which was resulted from the set-up of sekisho (barriers) and ritsubunsho (tax storehouses) supported both public and private economy.

Furthermore, as the monetary economy had developed in and after the Kamakura period, the kaeki-ken right (the right to levy duty, which was alternatively considered as the trade rights in Kyoto) was exercised against the 'za' (trade guilds) which had been descended from kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) as well as merchants and traders (who had to provide guji on his behalf with the produce and products by means of production and acquisition), and an income which was resulted from the set-up of sekisho (barriers) and ritsubunsho (tax storehouses) supported both public and private economy.

Furthermore, as the monetary economy had developed in and after the Kamakura period, the kaeki-ken right (the right to levy duty, which was alternatively considered as the trade rights in Kyoto) was exercised against the 'za' (trade guilds) which had been descended from kugonin (purveyors to the imperial household) as well as merchants and traders (who had to provide guji on his behalf with the produce and products by means of production and acquisition), and an income which was resulted from the set-up of sekisho (barriers) and ritsubunsho (tax storehouses) supported both public and private economy.

sen.j: 公家領は当初は次男以下への家領の分割による新しい家の分立（例、近衛家からの鷹司家分立）や女系による継承の例も見られたが、鎌倉時代後期になると公家領の拡大が鈍化して分割のみが進行する様になった。
sen.e: Kuge-ryo territory was originally inherited by founding a new branch family (e.g. the Takatsukasa family branched out from the Konoe family) based on the division and grant of keryo to the second or younger son, and, alternatively, matrilineal succession was possible, but in the late Kamakura period an expansion of kuge-ryo territory slowed down and merely a division of the kuge-ryo progressed.
sen.cmt: （例近衛家からの）→（例、近衛家からの）に修正しました。
sen.e: Kuge-ryo territory was originally inherited by founding a new branch family (e.g. the Takatsukasa family branched out from the Konoe family) based on the division and grant of keryo to the second or younger son, and, alternatively, matrilineal succession was possible, but in the late Kamakura period an expansion of kuge-ryo territory slowed down and merely a division of the kuge-ryo progressed.

Kuge-ryo territory was originally inherited by founding a new branch family (e.g. the Takatsukasa family branched out from the Konoe family) based on the division and grant of keryo to the second or younger son, and, alternatively, matrilineal succession was possible, but in the late Kamakura period an expansion of kuge-ryo territory slowed down and merely a division of the kuge-ryo progressed.

sen.j: このため、所領を巡る争いが頻発するようになり、鎌倉時代末期より本家や治天の君の裁許を求める例が増えるようになり、嫡男への男系相続へと移行するようになる。
sen.e: This caused a frequent occurrence of conflicts between the two parties wanting a shoryo (fief), which resulted in increasing calls for a judgment of the head family or the Chiten no kimi (the retired emperor in power), commencing the end of the Kamakura period, and the trend thus shifted to patrilineal inheritance to the eldest son (heir).

This caused a frequent occurrence of the conflicts concerning shoryo (fief), which resulted in increasing calls for judgments of the head family or the Chiten no kimi (the retired emperor in power), commencing the end of the Kamakura period, and the trend thus shifted to patrilineal inheritance to the eldest son (heir).
sen.cmt: the を挿入し、between the two parties wanting→concerning,a judgment→judgments と修正しました。
sen.e: This caused a frequent occurrence of the conflicts concerning shoryo (fief), which resulted in increasing calls for judgments of the head family or the Chiten no kimi (the retired emperor in power), commencing the end of the Kamakura period, and the trend thus shifted to patrilineal inheritance to the eldest son (heir).

sen.j: それを受けて建武政権においては後醍醐天皇が家督・家記・邸宅などを合わせて「家門」とし、家領を家門維持のために必要な経済的な基盤としてと位置づけ、本家・領家を問わず家門と家領を家単位で一括安堵をする仕組を取り入れたのである。
sen.e: In response to that, under the Kenmu regime Emperor Godaigo adopted a mechanism such that katoku (family estate), kaki (family record) and a residence were incorporated into 'kamon' (family), keryo (territory of a family) was positioned as the economic basis needed to maintain the kamon, collectively providing 'shoryo ando' (act of providing authorization for land ownership and guaranteeing feudal tenure) to kamon and keryo for each family, regardless of its being the honke or ryoke.

In response to that, under the Kenmu regime the Emperor Godaigo adopted a mechanism such that katoku (family estate), kaki (family record) and residence were incorporated into 'kamon' (family), keryo (territory of a family) was positioned as the economic basis needed to maintain the kamon, collectively providing 'shoryo ando' (act of providing authorization for land ownership and guaranteeing feudal tenure) to kamon and keryo for each family, regardless of its being the honke or ryoke.
sen.cmt: the を挿入し、a を削除 しました。
sen.e: In response to that, under the Kenmu regime the Emperor Godaigo adopted a mechanism such that katoku (family estate), kaki (family record) and residence were incorporated into 'kamon' (family), keryo (territory of a family) was positioned as the economic basis needed to maintain the kamon, collectively providing 'shoryo ando' (act of providing authorization for land ownership and guaranteeing feudal tenure) to kamon and keryo for each family, regardless of its being the honke or ryoke.

sen.j: 家門・家領の一括安堵は建武政権を倒す形で成立した北朝 (日本)においても継承され、嫡男への男系相続への移行を決定づけたのである。
sen.e: This mechanism of the collective provision of 'shoryo ando' (which was called 'ikkatsu ando' in Japanese) with respect to kamon and keryo was also adopted and succeeded by the Northern Court (of Japan) which had been established by toppling the Kenmu regime, thereby determining the shift to patrilineal succession to the eldest son (heir).

This mechanism of the collective provision of 'shoryo ando' (which was called 'ikkatsu ando' in Japanese) with respect to the kamon and keryo was also adopted and succeeded by the Northern Court (of Japan) which had been established by toppling the Kenmu regime, thereby determining the shift to patrilineal succession to the eldest son (heir).

This mechanism of the collective provision of 'shoryo ando' (which was called 'ikkatsu ando' in Japanese) with respect to the kamon and keryo was also adopted and succeeded by the Northern Court (of Japan) which had been established by toppling the Kenmu regime, thereby determining the shift to patrilineal succession to the eldest son (heir).

sen.j: だが、南北朝の内乱の中で室町幕府による半済令が行われ、更に寺社本所領事によって、皇室領・摂関家の渡領などを例外として実質上の守護大名との下地中分が行われた。
sen.e: However, the hanzeirei (an order allowing military governors, or shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) was enacted by the Muromachi shogunate during internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts, and besides, the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of a shoen between competing central and local claimants) was performed with shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors that became daimyo) with an exception of the case of watari ryo (the land which the Fujiwara family hereditarily succeeded) including the territories of the imperial household and the sekkan-ke families, due to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act (an act issued by the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, which was a collection of basic policies of the Muromachi shogunate regarding territorial lawsuits).

However, the hanzeirei (an order allowing military governors, or shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) was enacted by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts, and besides, the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of a shoen between competing central and local claimants) was performed with shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors that became daimyo) with an exception of the case of watari ryo (the land which the Fujiwara family hereditarily succeeded) including the territories of the imperial household and the sekkan-ke families, due to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act (an act issued by the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, which was a collection of basic policies of the Muromachi bakufu regarding territorial lawsuits).
sen.cmt: shogunate→bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) と修正しました。
sen.e: However, the hanzeirei (an order allowing military governors, or shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) was enacted by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts, and besides, the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of a shoen between competing central and local claimants) was performed with shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors that became daimyo) with an exception of the case of watari ryo (the land which the Fujiwara family hereditarily succeeded) including the territories of the imperial household and the sekkan-ke families, due to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act (an act issued by the third shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, which was a collection of basic policies of the Muromachi bakufu regarding territorial lawsuits).

sen.j: しかし、室町幕府の軍事力によって維持される存在となっていた公家政権に抗うことは不可能であった。
sen.e: It was impossible, however, to resist the kuge administration which was maintained by the military force of the Muromachi shogunate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was impossible, however, to resist the kuge administration which was maintained by the military force of the Muromachi bakufu.
It was impossible, however, to resist the kuge administration which was maintained by the military force of the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: そして、足利義満が治天の君が持っていた政治的権限（王権）を自己の手中に収めていく過程において従来治天の君が保有していた一括安堵の権限をも掌握していき、義満以後においても天皇の綸旨のみならず室町殿の御教書・御内書を必要とした。
sen.e: In addition, as Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA began to take hold of the political authority (sovereignty) which the Chiten no kimi used to possess, Yoshimitsu also took control of the authority to perform the 'ikkatsu ando' which was also entertained by the Chiten no kimi, thus requiring not only the rinji (the personal edict of the emperor) but the Shogun's migyosho (a documented shogunal order) and gonaisho (a letter issued over the signature of the shogun) which were issued at the Muromachi dono Palace, even after Yoshimitsu's reign.

In addition, as Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA began to take hold of the political authority (sovereignty) which the Chiten no kimi used to possess, Yoshimitsu also took control of the authority to perform the 'ikkatsu ando' which was also held by the Chiten no kimi, thus requiring not only the rinji (the personal edict of the emperor) but the shogun's migyosho (a documented shogunal order) and gonaisho (a letter issued over the signature of the shogun) which were issued at the Muromachi dono Palace, even after the Yoshimitsu's reign.
sen.cmt: entertained→held,Shogun→shogun と修正し、the を挿入しました。
sen.e: In addition, as Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA began to take hold of the political authority (sovereignty) which the Chiten no kimi used to possess, Yoshimitsu also took control of the authority to perform the 'ikkatsu ando' which was also held by the Chiten no kimi, thus requiring not only the rinji (the personal edict of the emperor) but the shogun's migyosho (a documented shogunal order) and gonaisho (a letter issued over the signature of the shogun) which were issued at the Muromachi dono Palace, even after the Yoshimitsu's reign.

sen.j: 天皇の綸旨は家督や家業の安堵の役目を、室町殿の御教書・御内書は家領の安堵の役目を果たした。
sen.e: The emperor's rinji (order) played a role of providing an authorization called 'ando' for the ownership of a family estate and guaranteeing the family business, while the Shogun's migyosho and gonaisho played a role of providing an 'ando' authorization for the ownership of keryo (territory of a family).

The emperor's rinji (order) played a role of providing an authorization called 'ando' for the ownership of the family estate and guaranteeing the family business, while the shogun's migyosho and gonaisho played a role of providing an 'ando' authorization for the ownership of keryo (territory of a family).
sen.cmt: a family estate→the family estate,Shogun→shogun と修正しました。
sen.e: The emperor's rinji (order) played a role of providing an authorization called 'ando' for the ownership of the family estate and guaranteeing the family business, while the shogun's migyosho and gonaisho played a role of providing an 'ando' authorization for the ownership of keryo (territory of a family).

sen.j: ただし、安堵の主導権を天皇と室町殿のどちらが握っているかは時期により差があった。
sen.e: Note that a question of which authority, the emperor or the shogun, took the initiative with regard to the 'ando' authorization depended on a time period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Note that the question of which authority, the emperor or the shogun, took the initiative with regard to the 'ando' authorization depended on the period of time.
sen.cmt: a→the,a time period→the period of time と修正しました。
sen.e: Note that the question of which authority, the emperor or the shogun, took the initiative with regard to the 'ando' authorization depended on the period of time.

sen.j: 義持・足利義教の時代に入っても室町殿による家門安堵の例が多く見られるものの、嘉吉の変以後はもっぱら天皇が家門を安堵し、それを受けて室町殿が家領の安堵する形式がほとんどとなる。
sen.e: Even at the time of Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, there could be seen many cases of the kamon ando (guarantee to a family) by the Muromachi dono (the Shogun), but after the Kakitsu incident, it was mainly the emperor who first provided an ando authorization to a family, which was then followed by the shogun providing an ando authorization to keryo territory.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even at the time of Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, there could be seen many cases of the kamon ando (guarantee to a family) by the Muromachi dono (the Shogun), but after the Kakitsu Incident, it was mainly the emperor who first provided the ando authorization to the families, which was then followed by the shogun providing the ando authorization to keryo territories.
sen.cmt: incident→Incident,an→the,a family→the families,territory→territories と修正しました。
sen.e: Even at the time of Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, there could be seen many cases of the kamon ando (guarantee to a family) by the Muromachi dono (the Shogun), but after the Kakitsu Incident, it was mainly the emperor who first provided the ando authorization to the families, which was then followed by the shogun providing the ando authorization to keryo territories.

sen.j: また、室町殿による家領安堵とは反対に室町殿の意向に反した公家の所領没収も行われる場合もあり、広橋家のように足利義持・義教の2代の征夷大将軍から家領を没収された例もあった。
sen.e: Further, in contrast to the keryo ando which was performed by the shogun, there was the confiscation of the shoryo property of the kuge who had objected a decision of the shogun, as the Hirohashi family who was deprived of the keryo property by Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, the two successive Seii taishogun (literally, the 'great general who subdues the barbarians').

Further, in contrast to the keryo ando which was handled by the shogun, there was the confiscation of the shoryo properties of the kuge who had objected a decision of the shogun, as the Hirohashi family who was deprived of the keryo property by Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, the two successive seii taishogun (literally, the "great general who subdues the barbarians").

Further, in contrast to the keryo ando which was handled by the shogun, there was the confiscation of the shoryo properties of the kuge who had objected a decision of the shogun, as the Hirohashi family who was deprived of the keryo property by Yoshimochi and Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, the two successive seii taishogun (literally, the "great general who subdues the barbarians").

sen.j: 応仁の乱・明応の政変以後も室町殿による家領安堵の権限が完全には失われていなかったことは、(1) 室町幕府最後の時期に加賀国井家荘を巡って二条晴良と勧修寺晴右が争った際に正親町天皇が晴右に安堵する裁決を下したにも関わらず、将軍足利義昭が晴右が前将軍足利義栄の支持者であったことを理由に勅命を無視して晴良に安堵したこと、(2) 義昭の後ろ盾である織田信長から公家に対する朱印状が義昭の「仰」「御下知」に従って発給されていたことからも理解できる。
sen.e: It is clear that the Muromachi dono (the Shogun) did not completely lose his authority to grant the keryo ando after the Onin War and the Meio Coup, from the following fact that (1) when Haruyoshi NIJO and Haresuke KAJUJI disputed the Inoie sho manor in Kaga Province at the end of the reign of the Muromachi shogunate, despite Emperor Ogimachi's decision to provide an ando guarantee to Haresuke, Shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA neglected this imperial decision and provided the ando to Haruyoshi on the grounds that Haresuke had supported the previous shogun Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, and that (2) Nobunaga ODA who backed up Yoshiaki issued shuinjo (a shogunal license for foreign trade which was bearing the scarlet seal of the shogun) to the kuge nobles in response to Yoshiaki's 'gyo' and 'gogeji' (shogunal directive).
sen.cmt: 文中に、（１）・（２）の数字を付記しました。
sen.e: It is clear that the Muromachi dono (the Shogun) did not completely lose his authority to grant the keryo ando after the Onin War and the Meio Coup, from this two following facts: (1) when Haruyoshi NIJO and Haresuke KAJUJI disputed the Inoie sho manor in Kaga Province at the end of the reign of the Muromachi shogunate, despite the Emperor Ogimachi's decision to provide an ando guarantee to Haresuke, the Shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA neglected this imperial decision and provided the ando to Haruyoshi on the grounds that Haresuke had supported the previous shogun Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, (2) Nobunaga ODA who backed up Yoshiaki issued shuinjo (a shogunal license for foreign trade which was bearing the scarlet seal of the shogun) to the kuge nobles in response to Yoshiaki's 'gyo' and 'gogeji' (shogunal directive).
sen.cmt: from the following fact→from this two following facts,the を挿入し、コロンを挿入し、箇条毎の繋ぎ部分をスムースに修正しました。
sen.e: It is clear that the Muromachi dono (the Shogun) did not completely lose his authority to grant the keryo ando after the Onin War and the Meio Coup, from this two following facts: (1) when Haruyoshi NIJO and Haresuke KAJUJI disputed the Inoie sho manor in Kaga Province at the end of the reign of the Muromachi shogunate, despite the Emperor Ogimachi's decision to provide an ando guarantee to Haresuke, the Shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA neglected this imperial decision and provided the ando to Haruyoshi on the grounds that Haresuke had supported the previous shogun Yoshihide ASHIKAGA, (2) Nobunaga ODA who backed up Yoshiaki issued shuinjo (a shogunal license for foreign trade which was bearing the scarlet seal of the shogun) to the kuge nobles in response to Yoshiaki's 'gyo' and 'gogeji' (shogunal directive).

sen.j: 南北朝の内乱から寺社本所領事による下地中分の過程で京都周辺以外の公家領の多くは「不知行」化されて収入が全く入ってこない名目上だけの存在となる。
sen.e: During the time between the beginning of the internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts and the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of the land, shoen, between competing central and local claimants) which was performed according to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act, the land and land rights of a large number of kuge-ryo territories outside the capital area (Kyoto and the neighboring regions) were unlawfully seized by local warriors ('bushi') and no longer functioned as chigyo ('fuchigyo'), thus plundered ex-chigyo remained nominal and ceased to be the source of income for its lawful proprietors.
sen.cmt: 「不知行」かされて → 「不知行」化されて に修正しました。 「不知行化」の具体的描写は下記を参照しました。http://www.nsu.ac.jp/nsu_j/kikan/lab/e-asia/h20-5.pdf
sen.e: During the time between the beginning of the internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts and the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of the land, shoen, between competing central and local claimants) which was handled according to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act, the land and land rights of a large number of kuge-ryo territories outside the capital area (Kyoto and the neighboring regions) were unlawfully seized by local warriors ('bushi') and no longer functioned as chigyo ('fuchigyo'), thus plundered ex-chigyo remained nominal and ceased to be the source of income for its lawful proprietors.

During the time between the beginning of the internal disturbances between the Northern and Southern Courts and the shitaji chubun (the territorial division of the land, shoen, between competing central and local claimants) which was handled according to the Jisha honjoryo no koto Act, the land and land rights of a large number of kuge-ryo territories outside the capital area (Kyoto and the neighboring regions) were unlawfully seized by local warriors ('bushi') and no longer functioned as chigyo ('fuchigyo'), thus plundered ex-chigyo remained nominal and ceased to be the source of income for its lawful proprietors.

sen.j: 京都周辺の公家領からの収入は室町殿の家領安堵によって座や商工業者への課役や関所・率分所などからの収入とともに室町時代においても辛うじて維持されてきた。
sen.e: The income from the kuge-ryo in Kyoto and the surrounding area, along with the revenue of a tax levied on trade guilds ('za') and merchants and tradesmen as well as the income from barriers ('sekisho') and tax storehouses ('ritsubunsho'), managed to be sustained due to the effect of the shogunal guarantee on the family estate ('keryo ando').
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The income from the kuge-ryo in Kyoto and the surrounding area, along with the revenue of the tax levied on the trade guilds ('za') and the merchants and tradesmen, as well as the income from the barriers ('sekisho') and tax storehouses ('ritsubunsho'), managed to be sustained to the Muromachi period by the shogunal guarantee on the family estate ('keryo ando').
sen.cmt: the, カンマを挿入し、a→the,due to the effect of→by,”室町時代においても”の部分を補いました。
sen.e: The income from the kuge-ryo in Kyoto and the surrounding area, along with the revenue of the tax levied on the trade guilds ('za') and the merchants and tradesmen, as well as the income from the barriers ('sekisho') and tax storehouses ('ritsubunsho'), managed to be sustained to the Muromachi period by the shogunal guarantee on the family estate ('keryo ando').

sen.j: しかし、応仁の乱以後は現地の武士達に対する押領によってほとんどの公家領は「不知行」となり、経済・治安の混乱は関銭収入の維持も困難とした。
sen.e: After the Onin War, however, most of the kuge-ryo turned to 'fuchigyo' which ceased to function properly due to unlawful seizure of land and land rights by local warriors ('bushi'), and the confused status of economy and social security made it difficult to maintain the income of barrier fees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the Onin War, however, most of the kuge-ryo turned to 'fuchigyo' which ceased to function properly due to the unlawful seizure of land and land rights by the local warriors ('bushi'), and the confused status of economy and social security made it difficult to maintain the income of barrier fees.

After the Onin War, however, most of the kuge-ryo turned to 'fuchigyo' which ceased to function properly due to the unlawful seizure of land and land rights by the local warriors ('bushi'), and the confused status of economy and social security made it difficult to maintain the income of barrier fees.

sen.j: 公家たちは生活のために京都を離れて地方の戦国大名を頼ったり、自己の荘園に移住して直務（荘園の直接経営）を行ったりする例も現れるようになった。
sen.e: The nobles ('kuge') in need had to flee from Kyoto to distant regions where they resorted to Sengoku daimyo (warlords) for help, or alternatively, some of them embarked on the direct management ('jikimu') of their own shoen manor wherein they lived.

The nobles ('kuge') in need had to flee from Kyoto to distant regions where they resorted to the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) for help, or alternatively, some of them embarked on the direct management ('jikimu') of their own shoen manor wherein they lived.
sen.cmt: ”戦国大名”を修正しました（用語統一）。
sen.e: The nobles ('kuge') in need had to flee from Kyoto to distant regions where they resorted to the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) for help, or alternatively, some of them embarked on the direct management ('jikimu') of their own shoen manor wherein they lived.

sen.j: 織田信長や豊臣秀吉は公家に対して残された所領の安堵や新規の知行の給付を行った。
sen.e: The two prominent Sengoku daimyo, Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, guaranteed ('ando') the remaining landholding ('shoryo') of the kuge nobles and provided them with new fiefs ('chigyo').
The two prominent Sengoku daimyo, Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, guaranteed ('ando') the remaining landholding ('shoryo') of the kuge nobles and provided them with new fiefs ('chigyo').
The two prominent Sengoku daimyo, Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, guaranteed ('ando') the remaining landholding ('shoryo') of the kuge nobles and provided them with new fiefs ('chigyo').

sen.j: 続いて徳川家康も関ヶ原の戦いに勝利すると直ちに公家領の調査を行い、禁裏御料（皇室領）以下の公家・門跡領の知行を宛がっている。
sen.e: Next, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, on his victory at the Battle of Sekigahara, commenced research on the kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the kuge nobles), thereby allotting fiefs ('chigyo') among the court nobles, which included the kinri goryo (the imperial property), the kuge-ryo and the monzeki-ryo (the property of an imperial priest of a temple at which the head priest had always been a member of the imperial family or of the nobility).

Next, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, on his victory at the Battle of Sekigahara, commenced the research on the kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the kuge nobles), thereby allotting the fiefs ('chigyo') among the court nobles, which included the kinri goryo (the imperial property), the kuge-ryo and the monzeki-ryo (the property of an imperial priest of a temple at which the head priest had always been a member of the imperial family or of the nobility).
sen.cmt: the research. the fiefs と修正しました。
sen.e: Next, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, on his victory at the Battle of Sekigahara, commenced the research on the kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the kuge nobles), thereby allotting the fiefs ('chigyo') among the court nobles, which included the kinri goryo (the imperial property), the kuge-ryo and the monzeki-ryo (the property of an imperial priest of a temple at which the head priest had always been a member of the imperial family or of the nobility).

sen.j: この際、宮家・公家領はあわせて3万石弱であり、宮家では八条宮家の3,000石、伏見宮家の1,000石などとされ、公家では近衛家の2,295石余以下、新設の新家に至っては50石という事例も珍しくなかった。
sen.e: On that occasion, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miya-ke families (families of Miya, i.e. princes and princesses) and the kuge was nearly 30,000 koku, wherein the Miya-ke families included the Hachijonomiya family of 3,000 koku and the Fushiminomiya family of 1,000 koku, whereas the kuge included the Konoe family of 2,295 koku as the top and a newly founded family of 50 koku which was not rare.
sen.cmt: 「2,295石余」とありますが、数字が具体的なのに対して「余」とつけるのは矛盾しませんでしょうか？英語では矛盾する為「余」は訳出しておりません。 念のためご確認願います。
sen.e: On that occasion, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miyake (house of an imperial prince) and the kuge was nearly 30,000 koku, wherein the Miya-ke families included the Hachijonomiya family of 3,000 koku and the Fushiminomiya family of 1,000 koku, whereas the kuge included the Konoe family of 2,295 koku as the top, and a newly founded family of 50 koku which was not rare.
sen.cmt: ”宮家”を修正しました。カンマを挿入しました。「2,295石余」の件に関しては、私では判断できませんのでそのままにしてあります。
sen.e: On that occasion, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miyake (house of an imperial prince) and the kuge was nearly 30,000 koku, wherein the Miya-ke families included the Hachijonomiya family of 3,000 koku and the Fushiminomiya family of 1,000 koku, whereas the kuge included the Konoe family of 2,295 koku as the top, and a newly founded family of 50 koku which was not rare.

sen.j: なお、江戸時代中期には宮家・公家106家で合わせて46,600石となっている。
sen.e: Incidentally, in the middle of the Edo period, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miya-ke families and 106 kuge families was 46,600 koku.
Incidentally, in the middle of the Edo period, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miyake and kuge, 106 families in total, was 46,600 koku.
sen.cmt: Miya-ke→Miyake,”宮家・公家106家”の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: Incidentally, in the middle of the Edo period, the sum of the size of the landholdings of the Miyake and kuge, 106 families in total, was 46,600 koku.

sen.j: これは家格や家自体の新旧、江戸幕府や天皇との親疎による（昵懇衆とされた公家は家格が低くても家領は多い）。
sen.e: It depended on various conditions, such as the family status ('kakaku'), the length of the history of a family, and a question of whether a family was close to the Edo bakufu or the emperor (N.B. some kuge nobles called 'jikkon shu' [literally, people on friendly terms] had large 'keryo' landholdings even if their family status was not high.)
sen.cmt: 原文文末が「親疎」で途切れていましたので、「による」を補足しました。（尚、ウェブサイト上の文言も途切れたままです。）
sen.e: It depends on various conditions, such as the family status ('kakaku'), the length of the history of a family, and a question of whether a family was close to the Edo bakufu or the emperor (some kuge nobles called 'jikkon shu' [literally, people on friendly terms] had large 'keryo' landholdings even if their family status was not high.)
sen.cmt: depended→depends と修正しました。（時勢は原文のままに従いました）カッコ内の"N.B."は不必要なので削除しました。
sen.e: It depends on various conditions, such as the family status ('kakaku'), the length of the history of a family, and a question of whether a family was close to the Edo bakufu or the emperor (some kuge nobles called 'jikkon shu' [literally, people on friendly terms] had large 'keryo' landholdings even if their family status was not high.)

sen.j: 公家に対する知行安堵は大臣家以上及び従一位には征夷大将軍からの判物、それ以下には朱印状をもって行われた（武家の場合は10万石以上を判物、それ未満を朱印状としている）。
sen.e: When the shogun guaranteed fiefs ('chigyo ando') to the kuge nobles, a document with autographic signature of the Seii taishogun which was called 'hanmono' was granted to the daijin-ke families (the third highest status for court nobles) or the superior and those of Junior First Rank, and a 'shuinjo' letter to the others of lower rank (N.B. in the case of warrior households called 'buke', the hanmono was granted to those of 100,000 koku or more, and the shuinjo to the others of less koku than that.)

When the shogun guaranteed fiefs ('chigyo ando') to the kuge nobles, the document with autographic signature of the seii taishogun which was called 'hanmono' was granted to the daijin-ke families (the third highest status for court nobles) or the superior and those of the Junior First Rank, and the 'shuinjo' letter to the others of lower rank (in the case of warrior households called 'buke,' the hanmono was granted to those of 100,000 koku or more, and the shuinjo to the others of less koku than that.)
sen.cmt: a→the,Seii→seii,the を挿入し、クォーツ内のカンマの位置を修正しました。カッコ内の"N.B."は不必要なので削除しました。
sen.e: When the shogun guaranteed fiefs ('chigyo ando') to the kuge nobles, the document with autographic signature of the seii taishogun which was called 'hanmono' was granted to the daijin-ke families (the third highest status for court nobles) or the superior and those of the Junior First Rank, and the 'shuinjo' letter to the others of lower rank (in the case of warrior households called 'buke,' the hanmono was granted to those of 100,000 koku or more, and the shuinjo to the others of less koku than that.)

sen.j: この他に御方と呼ばれた嫡子の出仕者に方領と呼ばれる所領が家督継承までの間与えられることがあった。
sen.e: Further, there were some cases that landholding called 'horyo' (fief) was granted to a court attendant ('shusshisha') who was the heir of a family and was called 'okata,' on condition that the grant was available until he inherited his family estate.

Further, there were some cases that landholding called 'horyo' (fief) was granted to a court attendant ('shusshisha') who was the heir of a family and was called 'okata,' on condition that the grant was available until he inherited his family estate.

Further, there were some cases that landholding called 'horyo' (fief) was granted to a court attendant ('shusshisha') who was the heir of a family and was called 'okata,' on condition that the grant was available until he inherited his family estate.

sen.j: だが、一部の家を除けば、小禄高の武士並の知行しか与えられず、その生活は苦しかった。
sen.e: Except for a few families, however, the okata was merely granted fief ('chigyo') of a low stipend ('sho rokudaka') which was as low as that of a bushi warrior, and therefore, he had to endure poverty.
Except for a few families, however, the okata was merely granted fief ('chigyo') which was as little as the low stipend ('sho rokudaka') samurai, and therefore, they had to endure poverty.
sen.cmt: bushi warrior→samurai, he→they と修正しました。”知行が武士並みに低かった”のではなく、”知行は小禄高の武士並み”と理解し、修正しました。
sen.e: Except for a few families, however, the okata was merely granted fief ('chigyo') which was as little as the low stipend ('sho rokudaka') samurai, and therefore, they had to endure poverty.
